attributes.title: NASA Heads to the Sun
attributes.description_short: NASA launched a new spacecraft to study the Sun like never before.
attributes.description_long: On August 12, 2018, NASA launched the Parker Solar Probe to study the Sun like never before. It will hurtle towards the star at the center of our solar system at 120 miles per second, which is the fastest human-made object ever. The heat shield on the front of the probe will withstand temperatures of about 2500 degrees Fahrenheit to keep the instruments at roughly room temperature.

attributes.title: Liquid Water Found on Mars
attributes.description_short: Scientists found a large body of liquid water beneath the southern ice caps of Mars.
attributes.description_long: A team of scientists recently discovered a large body of liquid water beneath the southern ice cap of Mars. The presence of liquid water, an essential ingredient for life as we know it, could help inform future studies for past and potentially extant life on the red planet. Explore the discovery made with radar technology and learn what scientists think about the potential of life on Mars.

attributes.title: How to Slow Down Time
attributes.description_short: In different but similar ways, both your brain and the laws of physics can slow down time.
attributes.description_long: Under the right circumstances, your brain can trick you into experiencing some time intervals as longer than others. But under other circumstances, time itself really does slow down. The two phenomena—psychological and physical—are more similar than you might think.

attributes.description_short: Puerto Ricans are innovating to find new energy solutions after Hurricane Maria.
attributes.description_long: Puerto Ricans are innovating to find new energy solutions after the storm revealed extreme weaknesses in the island’s electrical grid.

attributes.title: Macaque Monkeys Adapt After Hurricane Maria
attributes.title_sortable: Macaque Monkeys Adapt After Hurricane Maria
attributes.description_short: Researchers investigate whether 1800 macaques may have been changed by Hurricane Maria.
attributes.description_long: Over 1800 rhesus macaques inhabit the tiny island of Cayo Santiago just off the east coast of Puerto Rico. Most of these monkeys managed to survive Hurricane Maria, but researchers speculate that their behavior and cognition may have been altered. The reason is a change in availability of resources on the island, including that of shade.

attributes.description_short: The spinning of the Earth means we don't always see straight paths as straight.
attributes.description_long: The spinning of the Earth means we don't always see straight paths as straight.

attributes.title: The Arecibo Observatory
attributes.description_short: After Hurricane Maria, the Arecibo Observatory staff worked to rebuild its facility.
attributes.description_long: After Hurricane Maria, the Arecibo Observatory and its staff worked to rebuild its facility––home to the most powerful astronomical radar and one of the largest radio telescopes on Earth––and aid the neighboring community.

attributes.title: Modern Politics Activates the Brain's Ancient Wiring
attributes.title_sortable: Modern Politics Activates the Brain's Ancient Wiring
attributes.description_short: How does your brain process political ideas?
attributes.description_long: Research on the biology of political beliefs provides insight into the effectiveness of how to win any argument. Current theories suggest that people’s political beliefs are driven by their identification with a group—similar to sports team loyalties, but more rooted in values, which makes them harder to change. Processing political thoughts may be a simple question of "Us versus Them."
attributes.player_code: <iframe  id='partnerPlayer' frameborder='0' marginwidth='0' marginheight='0' scrolling='no' width='100%' height='100%' src='//player.pbs.org/partnerplayer/eKRLavWAA-ngoqxUbtx3Uw==/?topbar=false&end=0&endscreen=true&start=0&autoplay=false' allowfullscreen></iframe>

attributes.title: Winter Is Coming… And So Is Seasonal Depression
attributes.title_sortable: Winter Is Coming… And So Is Seasonal Depression
attributes.description_short: As the days shorten, our internal clocks have to recalibrate. But that's hard for some.
attributes.description_long: Gloomy, cloudy days and the transition from summer to winter are dreaded by many for the same reason: shorter days with less sunlight. Internal body clocks known as circadian rhythms help us adjust our sleep and wakefulness accordingly, but for some, the disruption might lead to a type of depression called Seasonal Affective Disorder.
attributes.player_code: <iframe  id='partnerPlayer' frameborder='0' marginwidth='0' marginheight='0' scrolling='no' width='100%' height='100%' src='//player.pbs.org/partnerplayer/E1XdUEucQH27BTXNT_Cd0A==/?topbar=false&end=0&endscreen=true&start=0&autoplay=false' allowfullscreen></iframe>

attributes.title: Turn to Science for Great Thanksgiving Stuffing
attributes.title_sortable: Turn to Science for Great Thanksgiving Stuffing
attributes.description_short: Learn the secret to making delicious stuffing that's not gummy.
attributes.description_long: What makes onions so oniony? Why does stuffing sometimes come out gummy? Learn the secret to making delicious stuffing with the perfect texture—and why onions might make you cry as you're cooking it.

attributes.title: Fireproofing Our Future through Better Design
attributes.title_sortable: Fireproofing Our Future through Better Design
attributes.description_short: Before a wildfire ever starts, there are ways to make homes and buildings safer.
attributes.description_long: California’s Camp and Woolsey Fires caused billions in property damage—and took dozens of human lives. Can we safeguard our homes and buildings from this degree of loss in the future? Approaches include keeping the outdoors surrounding a structure clear of combustible debris, building with materials that are inherently non-flammable, and retrofitting walls, vents, and roofs to prevent fires.
